sn3.14:1.2: Then King Ajatasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, mobilized an army of four divisions and marched to Kasi to attack King Pasenadi of Kosala.
sn3.14:1.3: When King Pasenadi heard of this,
sn3.14:1.5: he mobilized an army of four divisions and marched to Kasi to defend it against Ajatasattu.
sn3.14:1.6: Then the two kings met in battle.
sn3.14:1.7: And in that battle Ajatasattu defeated Pasenadi,
sn3.14:1.8: who withdrew to his own capital at Savatthi.
sn3.14:2.1: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Savatthi for alms.
sn3.14:2.2: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then the Buddha said:
sn3.14:4.1: “Mendicants, King Ajatasattu has bad friends, companions, and associates.
sn3.14:4.2: But King Pasenadi has good friends, companions, and associates.
sn3.14:4.3: Yet on this day King Pasenadi will have a bad night’s sleep as one defeated.”
sn3.14:4.4: That is what the Buddha said. …
sn3.14:5.4: having left victory and defeat behind.”
